title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 7 march [1865]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 7 March [1865]
text: 1865March 7 Walti have just got your letter i write to say sis is much better she has been down stairs to day and plays about she has lost some of her fat but will regain it again walt why dontdon't you write longer letters and say all about your affairs if you are is the same department and if you are well and all about it) it seems strange to get such short letters from you not even to say how you are i hope nothing has Occuredoccurred to make you uncomfortable i see your piece in the times yesterday i will get the eagles as you wish but be sure to write to me and write more particularly you will think i have nothing to doodo but write but i thought you would want to hear from sis and I want you to write to me without fail sam Pooley staidstayed here last night he is very well he has gone home to daytoday to BuffalowBuffalo he is very much attached to George he said when the Captain was sick he was A great mind to play sick to get in the hospital those skechessketches that sims gave George wright has never sent back George regrets loosing them he would not give them to any of the officers but george and told him to not let any of them get them away the history of the sketch is quite novel Major wright is going to resign and George i think will proballyprobably too good bie Walt write when you get this Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 7 March [1865]
